Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque Got it, that's what I thought. Ok, not freaked out anymore, I have it resolved in my head now. I have learned a couple of things about incontinence that may be helpful to some people, even though it's probably already common knowledge. #1 let the gas pass naturally, do not force for dramatic effect around your guy friends! #2 If you drink Coffee you will pay the price! I have not drank Alcohol yet but my guess is same as Coffee. #3 Try not to drink water after 7pm, it helps me stay dry all night and minimize waking up to go to the bathroom. #4 Sneezing and Hard coughing can cause some inadvertent dripping. #5 In my case trying to hold the pee in, if I have the urge to go, does not work very well. Thanks everyone! Hope that you have a nice undetectable PSA coming up! I seem to have the opposite issue with incontinence- I try to make sure I kegel when I cough, get up, etc. However, when I am standing I have regularly started to leak without any warning. I haven't had anything with caffeine other than some chocolate- no coffee, tea, alcohol.

Posts.Content: There are a number of travel insurance companies and each one usually has several options to select from. One size does not fit all, and because of that it's a good idea to read the fine print as to when they will and won't pay, what the exclusions are, what the insurance company requires for you to get reimbursed, etc.

Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer I was told by my urologist that there can be small amounts of detectable PSA from saliva. Here is one study about it. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11096235

Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer I was told by my urologist that there can be small amounts of detectable PSA from saliva. Here is one study about it. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11096235

Posts.Title: Try to stay positive

Posts.Content: First PSA follow up is 6 weeks post surgery, give or take a few days. I do ok when I'm coughing, getting up from sitting, etc., but when I stand or walk I am prone to leaking semi-regularly. None of them is a large volume, but they do add up over the course of a day. I was a semi-gym rat prior to the surgery, and a 6 week moratorium is difficult. I even did special kegel routines lying on the floor that I found on youtube pre-surgery. My doc doesn't want me to do more than a few kegels at the end of the day (he wants me to incorporate kegels into normal activity) which is similar to what Mayo Clinic recommends. This is opposite of what the physical therapy group that specializes in incontinence recommends. This reminds me of eggs are bad for you, no- eggs are good for you, butter is bad for you, no- it's good for you, etc. Yesterday I noticed blood in my urine, but today there hasn't been a second occurrence. I would gladly take your results so far especially since it hasn't even been two weeks post catheter for you. I'm not frustrated yet, but it's not easy regressing to being 3 years old again. I've also had penile shrinkage which is another humbling result. I know that living a full life trumps the side effects.

AgeInfo.Phrase: not easy regressing to being 3 years old again <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: I wish I could report the same degree of success as you. I am still in the full depends underwear and had my surgery 2 days before you. I wonder if the size of my prostate (more than double yours) disrupts more nerves and tissue which in turn takes longer to repair itself. If you're almost continent at this point, seems to be your call as to whether you think the time, effort, copay would be worth a very small improvement (which might not even be required if you wait a few more weeks).

Posts.Title: A Question About Bio Feedback For Incontenance

Posts.Content: Msr. DaVinci and I were supposed to meet at 7:30 AM on Sept. 25. Got the call I didn't want informing me that the time had been changed to 10:30. Go to the hospital to get prepped by 9:45, sitting and waiting to get called. Finally at 12:15 my surgeon walks in and says it's going to be in about 15 minutes. In the meanwhile my BP has been setting a new Guinness record. Get positioned on the table and at the other end of the room I see the robot, and the next thing I know I'm in recovery about 3.5 hours later. First night started out ok but I must have had a reaction to the anesthesia as I got clammy, dizzy, and nauseous so they gave me something to help. Had my first walk around 10 PM- not too bad. I'm not sure when it started, but as the gasses in my stomach kept building, the pressure and pain in my abs kept getting worse. The pain when I coughed (which happened all too frequently) was very bad. I work out core at least 2 times a week out of 6 and it felt like nothing I had experienced. I tip my hat to those that didn't experience that. My doc came in the room the day after surgery after one of my coughing spells and I told him I wasn't ready to leave. Stayed one more night which was less than restful but about an hour before I was to be released the next day I passed gas and the pain wasn't quite as bad. They also gave me and abdominal binder which is worthwhile. Allowed me to be able to get in and out of the car decently well and reduces pain when coughing. Coming back home was a challenge trying to get comfortable and dealing with my new friend Mr. Catheter. Decided to use my mother's old walker to hang the bag to keep it nice and low. It's an irritant but not all that bad. Takes some new tricks to be able to get dressed. They didn't give me any cream or recommend anything, but I can tolerate the feeling for now. The good part (so far) is that there is no blood in the urine and after the home care nurse took off the 6 outside dressings, the wounds are healing well. Sounds like the nerves were spared but the doc is very reluctant to give out much information until he sees pathology other than things went well. Hope the tumor behind the bladder didn't intrude elsewhere. I got on the scale today and for some unknown reason I gained 6 lbs since the day before my prep. So after eating jello and pop sickles on Sunday, ice chips on Monday, clear liquids on Tuesday, yogurt, scrambled eggs, and soup on Wednesday I gained weight. There is no justice. Going for a Cystogram Monday and if those results look OK then probably catheter removal the following day. Then a big plunge into the dark with continence and sexual function.

Posts.Title: Post RALP Report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD You gained weight because of the fluids they pump into you during surgery and after. It's fluid retention. I gained 10 lbs, but after about a week, I started losing that. About the catheter - keep it cleaned and lubed to prevent any issues. Clean with a was cloth, soap and water and lube the entry point twice per day using a Q-tip. All actions should be done wiping away from the opening of the penis to help prevent infection. Don't be surprised if at some point the urine in the bag ooks green. They said is was from blue dye that they used during surgery. Combine that with yellow urine and you get green. Thanks for the tips Dave!

Posts.Title: Post RALP Report

Posts.Content: Appreciate your interest and support. Yes, it could be that the doc had to manipulate the DaVinci more to extract the tumor. He said it was close to the prostate and had to remove the seminal vessels to get to it. Would be nice if the pain subsided some more within the next few days- either that or if it was possible, stop coughing. At the hospital they liked the fact that I was coughing to reduce the chance for pneumonia. To be honest, as of today I'm somewhat more worried about incontinence than the pathology since (according to the biopsy) I wasn't dealing with an aggressive cancer- yet.

I gained 10 lbs, but after about a week, I started losing that. About the catheter - keep it cleaned and lubed to prevent any issues. Clean with a was cloth, soap and water and lube the entry point twice per day using a Q-tip. All actions should be done wiping away from the opening of the penis to help prevent infection. Don't be surprised if at some point the urine in the bag ooks green. They said is was from blue dye that they used during surgery. Combine that with yellow urine and you get green. Thanks for the tips Dave!

Posts.Title: Post RALP Report

Posts.Content: Msr. DaVinci and I were supposed to meet at 7:30 AM on Sept. 25. Got the call I didn't want informing me that the time had been changed to 10:30. Go to the hospital to get prepped by 9:45, sitting and waiting to get called. Finally at 12:15 my surgeon walks in and says it's going to be in about 15 minutes. In the meanwhile my BP has been setting a new Guinness record. Get positioned on the table and at the other end of the room I see the robot, and the next thing I know I'm in recovery about 3.5 hours later. First night started out ok but I must have had a reaction to the anesthesia as I got clammy, dizzy, and nauseous so they gave me something to help. Had my first walk around 10 PM- not too bad. I'm not sure when it started, but as the gasses in my stomach kept building, the pressure and pain in my abs kept getting worse. The pain when I coughed (which happened all too frequently) was very bad. I work out core at least 2 times a week out of 6 and it felt like nothing I had experienced. I tip my hat to those that didn't experience that. My doc came in the room the day after surgery after one of my coughing spells and I told him I wasn't ready to leave. Stayed one more night which was less than restful but about an hour before I was to be released the next day I passed gas and the pain wasn't quite as bad. They also gave me and abdominal binder which is worthwhile. Allowed me to be able to get in and out of the car decently well and reduces pain when coughing. Coming back home was a challenge trying to get comfortable and dealing with my new friend Mr. Catheter. Decided to use my mother's old walker to hang the bag to keep it nice and low. It's an irritant but not all that bad. Takes some new tricks to be able to get dressed. They didn't give me any cream or recommend anything, but I can tolerate the feeling for now. The good part (so far) is that there is no blood in the urine and after the home care nurse took off the 6 outside dressings, the wounds are healing well. Sounds like the nerves were spared but the doc is very reluctant to give out much information until he sees pathology other than things went well. Hope the tumor behind the bladder didn't intrude elsewhere. I got on the scale today and for some unknown reason I gained 6 lbs since the day before my prep. So after eating jello and pop sickles on Sunday, ice chips on Monday, clear liquids on Tuesday, yogurt, scrambled eggs, and soup on Wednesday I gained weight. There is no justice. Going for a Cystogram Monday and if those results look OK then probably catheter removal the following day. Then a big plunge into the dark with continence and sexual function.

Posts.Title: Post RALP Report

Posts.Content: Appreciate your interest and support. Yes, it could be that the doc had to manipulate the DaVinci more to extract the tumor. He said it was close to the prostate and had to remove the seminal vessels to get to it. Would be nice if the pain subsided some more within the next few days- either that or if it was possible, stop coughing. At the hospital they liked the fact that I was coughing to reduce the chance for pneumonia. To be honest, as of today I'm somewhat more worried about incontinence than the pathology since (according to the biopsy) I wasn't dealing with an aggressive cancer- yet.

Posts.Content: When I was exploring Cyberknife, the RO freely admitted that most of the work was done by their Physicist. You can certainly look at their credentials and at the facility's patient satisfaction, I'm not sure how you would do any more research on him/her unless perhaps there was a recent turnover.

Posts.Title: 1st post-prostatectomy PSA results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by john4803 Thanks, MichaelF and Highlander for the encouragement! The Bone Scan was also clear. Does anyone know anything about the Prolaris test for aggressiveness. I hope to have the results next week. I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best!

Posts.Title: Incisional hernia developed after RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by john4803 Thanks, MichaelF and Highlander for the encouragement! The Bone Scan was also clear. Does anyone know anything about the Prolaris test for aggressiveness. I hope to have the results next week. I'm not as knowledgeable as those who have been dealing with this for years, but I had a similar genetic test done called OncotypeDx GPS. In my case the blind biopsy showed I had Gleason 6, so the additional test was being done to evaluate whether active surveillance might be appropriate. I don't understand the logic in your case of the additional lab test (other than perhaps a confirmation of the biopsy). You should be relieved that the bone scan was negative. Maybe I missed it, but was a 3T MRI ordered? I would think that would be more helpful in determining a course of action than the genetic test. In any event, I wish you the best!

Posts.Title: Well, I just had another surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome to the forum, Stricks. Yes, prostatectomies have come a long way since 2000 and they can do things that were not possible before. It is good that some medications will still give him erections, but apparently the new one he is taking does not get him firm enough to penetrate? You have a good idea in going along with him to the uro, especially since it is a female doctor. Otherwise he could consider switching to a male uro for easier discussions. Personally, my own nerves were spared with robotic surgery in 2011. But I had a prostate that was 4x normal size. In the years prior to my PC diagnosis, the huge prostate had already been squeezing my nerves "between a rock and a hard place." The effect of this was trauma to the nerves, which had neutralized my ability to get an erection. Even with nerve sparing surgery, the damage had already been done to my erectile nerves. Cialis has not worked for me and I cannot afford to give Viagra a try, so I'm kind of in "limbo" sexually speaking. As with you, my gf and myself do a lot of mutual oral sex whenever we decide to be intimate. One thing that can work, although I'm not comfortable with it, is a "penis pump," which places the penis into a long plastic tube that creates a vacuum -- and thus bringing the penis up to full hardness as long as the seal is not broken. There are tension rings that can be rolled off the tube to the base of the penis to maintain the erection for intercourse. We tried it and it didn't work very well for me because I probably did not do it right. Takes some practice. He may want to try and one of these devices. In April, when I return to Mayo Clinic for my annual general physical, I am scheduled to receive a penile injection. These, from my understanding, are almost foolproof and will create a good erection. So he may want to look into injections. I don't know if I'll have the courage to inject myself (at Mayo they make a guy jab himself in front of the nurse) to show that I am capable of self-injecting. I suppose I'll give it a try -- and your bf may want to consider the same thing. I believe the injections are pretty expensive, but supposedly they do work. Good luck to both of you! Chuck Just wondering about your comment. How are you able to obtain Cialis for a reasonable price while Viagra is unaffordable? I have the opposite situation- I purchase Sildenafil (Viagra generic) for $30/month out of pocket, while from what I have read I would be lucky to find Cialis for $30 a pill. I'm staying away from Cialis based on cost, but I would really like to see if it might be more effective than Sildenafil. Any tips on how to cut costs for Cialis (or it's generic equivalent) would be appreciated!

Posts.Title: Wondering about the effectiveness of Trimix

Posts.Content: Very similar to my experience, so don't feel that you are unique in this journey. My urologist said that most of the shrinkage is due to a reduction in blood flow due to the disruption caused by the surgery. I dont know if this video is validated, but I find it interesting nonetheless: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WicQ6m_CSuA

Posts.Title: Well, I just had another surgery

Posts.Content: The other aspect which I have no frame of reference for is the lack of being able to feel like I have to urinate like I did before. Before I could rate my need to urinate from a 1-10 in terms of urgency and now I can't really tell much of a difference. The stream is weaker than I had prior to surgery. I know sexual feeling is probably at the tail end of the recovery but it seems as if things are dormant. Yes, I freely admit I am not the model patient in terms of chilling I see my doc on Friday for an incontinence update and I think his need to see me this soon for that reason drives me to think that he believes there should be enough of a potential improvement to schedule the appointment.

Posts.Title: Incontinence questions

Posts.Content: Sorry that you are here. I have no first hand information for MO surgeons. However, you may find the data at least somewhat helpful if you search for Propublica/surgeons/MO/prostate removal. It will not tell you who is best, but it will give you some facts as to who has a higher than average complication rate along with a relative measure as to how many procedures are done. If it were me, I would avoid anyone in the red. If you have a local PC support group, I would contact them. Some are very helpful in sharing what they thought of the surgeons they used.

Posts.Title: Newbie to the forum

Posts.Content: I seem to be having the most leaking when I'm standing- not when I am getting up to stand but after a minute or two. I kegle as I get up, when I cough, etc. but it seems like standing still is my most frequent concern (although not the only one). Any insights that might help would be appreciated. Also, how much of continence improvement is due to passage of time post surgery as opposed to learning how/when to kegle?

Posts.Title: Incontinence questions

Posts.Content: The other aspect which I have no frame of reference for is the lack of being able to feel like I have to urinate like I did before. Before I could rate my need to urinate from a 1-10 in terms of urgency and now I can't really tell much of a difference. The stream is weaker than I had prior to surgery. I know sexual feeling is probably at the tail end of the recovery but it seems as if things are dormant. Yes, I freely admit I am not the model patient in terms of chilling I see my doc on Friday for an incontinence update and I think his need to see me this soon for that reason drives me to think that he believes there should be enough of a potential improvement to schedule the appointment.

Posts.Title: Incontinence questions

Posts.Content: Sorry that you are here. I have no first hand information for MO surgeons. However, you may find the data at least somewhat helpful if you search for Propublica/surgeons/MO/prostate removal. It will not tell you who is best, but it will give you some facts as to who has a higher than average complication rate along with a relative measure as to how many procedures are done. If it were me, I would avoid anyone in the red. If you have a local PC support group, I would contact them. Some are very helpful in sharing what they thought of the surgeons they used.

Posts.Title: Post Op Report - 3 Weeks and counting

Posts.Content: Trying to determine if there is much of a correlation between reacquiring continence and physical therapy. For those willing, would appreciate knowing how long it took you to be continent and approximately how often you did either/both informal kegel exercises or formal physical therapy. For those that didn't regain continence, did you try physical therapy? I'm going through a lot of effort as my physical therapy exercises become more numerous and more frequent (plus expensive) and would like to get a sense that there is a payoff doing that. I wonder how many do almost nothing and still regain continence which would suggest the normal healing process is the main driver of improvement. Thanks!

Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: Al- I was seeing the physical therapist every two weeks to start, and now its once per month. I recently added planks to my earlier assignment of bridges, lateral movements, squats, and rear kicks (all while doing kegels). I get homework assignments each time I go- the appointments are to see if I have any questions, then adding new exercises, then making sure I'm doing them correctly prior to leaving. I can kegel to avoid most of the stress incontinence, but there is leaking when I just stand for which I get no early warning signal. My pad consumption hasn't consistently decreased- some days are better than others but there are also bad days.

Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer I was told by my urologist that there can be small amounts of detectable PSA from saliva. Here is one study about it. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11096235

Posts.Title: Would this make you angry?

Posts.Content: I'm just two weeks past RALP and I have the same lack of feeling when to urinate. On a scale of 1-10 on knowing when I had to go, prior to RALP I was a 9 or 10, and now I'm a 2-3. I seem to do better when I'm sitting or laying down than when standing. My uneducated guess is that some of the nerves in the area of the prostate are disturbed and may take awhile before they function more like they used to. Since I'm rather cowardly, I'm still sleeping in my recliner in order to avoid having to wake up in the middle of the night to do sheets and undermine getting a good nights sleep. Hope we can both progress and put this behind us...

Posts.Title: Still incontinent. Now what.

Posts.Content: There is a PCA3 urine test which under some conditions can be ordered by your urologist. I had it done and was considered low risk from the results, but 6 months later when my PSA went up I had a biopsy and was diagnosed (see signature below). I later went to the Cleveland Clinic and their opinion is that PCA3 is not very good for other than 3 circumstances, none of which pertained to my situation (or yours as of now). I'm including the link to read more about those circumstances. http://portals.clevelandclinic.org/p...riefs/pca3.pdf Take it one step at a time, moving forward without adding more stress than necessary.

Posts.Title: How Bad is a PSA over 9?

Posts.Content: In case you hadn't seen this, I found a link which relates to the type of surgery you mentioned. Like most newer techniques, lack of track record makes it hard to evaluate. http://www.europeanurology.com/article/S0302-2838(16)30530-9/abstract/partial-prostatectomy-for-anterior-cancer-short-term-oncologic-and-functional-outcomes Continence for some comes quickly, and for others it takes some time. My experience has been that it is slowly improving, but I have yet to reach what I hope that will be a successful endpoint. Some will say that the more in shape you are will be a factor in a quicker recovery of continence, but in my case I had been working out hard 6 days a week for a few years prior to surgery, yet my recovery is still a work in process. It's certainly unnerving when your PSA rises fairly quickly even with Gleason 6. Nobody can say definitively that it will never morph into anything higher. There are other treatments involving focal therapies or radiation which have their pluses and minuses. Good idea to at least evaluate those before making a decision. Some may see a clear decision after this research, others will look at it as still a menu of side effects and how long it will take for them to either develop or be overcome. Ask your surgeon as to how many of these partial prostatectomy's have been done, and how many he has done. Also, did you have a genetic test done on the sampled Gleason 6 tissue? If it's higher risk, you should probably weigh whether a partial surgery would be the optimal treatment. Good luck, and if you have more questions fire away.

Posts.Content: If I'm reading your post correctly your PSA has been going up a little more than 10% per year for 3 years. The rate of increase isn't alarming, but the absolute number is concerning. Do you think that the infection was a fluke, or is there something the urologist did or didn't do that might have created a problem? Have you checked online reviews to see if others had a similar problem post biopsy? If it was me, I would be expecting a biopsy, but I would be doing my due diligence to ensure it was being done by someone I trusted. If your insurance pays for a second opinion, that might be a good idea.

Posts.Title: Should I have another biopsy

Posts.Content: First, the DRE isn't conclusive since the doctor can only feel a portion of the prostate. There is also some subjectivity to it. A reduction in ejaculate is called retrograde ejaculation which typically isn't a sign of any significant medical issue. However, a PSA of 9.11 is high- have you had any other PSA blood tests to compare it with to see how quickly its rising? It's good that you are seeing a Uro next. Its possible he/she will recommend a biopsy. It's too early to get upset but not too early to do your follow ups and make sure that you are comfortable with your Uro. Is there any prostrate cancer in your family? That could suggest a higher risk that you might be susceptible to it. Take things one step at a time and let us know when your appointment is and how it goes.

Posts.Title: Should I have another biopsy

Posts.Content: I was instructed not to be in a bath tub (or any other kind of tub) for at least 3 weeks after the surgery/catheter removal. The incisions are still healing at that point and there is the possibility of bacteria entering through those incisions. Did your surgeon provide you with any such instructions? A friend I met at a prostate cancer support group had bladder spasms that were very painful for a few months on and off after surgery. Fortunately I never had any. I'm not sure why some do and some don't, but I followed the doctors post surgical instructions to the letter to avoid any side effects that I could have some control over.

Posts.Title: First PSA test age 60

Posts.Content: First, the DRE isn't conclusive since the doctor can only feel a portion of the prostate. There is also some subjectivity to it. A reduction in ejaculate is called retrograde ejaculation which typically isn't a sign of any significant medical issue. However, a PSA of 9.11 is high- have you had any other PSA blood tests to compare it with to see how quickly its rising? It's good that you are seeing a Uro next. Its possible he/she will recommend a biopsy. It's too early to get upset but not too early to do your follow ups and make sure that you are comfortable with your Uro. Is there any prostrate cancer in your family? That could suggest a higher risk that you might be susceptible to it. Take things one step at a time and let us know when your appointment is and how it goes.

Posts.Title: Need your advice/suggestions ...

Posts.Content: That video is as slanted as the original sales job he got from the renowned surgeon. If the patient had done a little research, he would have seen red flags about allegations of concurrent surgeries being done. Also, if he had looked at Propublica, that surgeon has one of the highest complication rates anywhere. Another hint- do a google search on the doctor who was doing the interview of the dissatisfied patient and see what many of his other patients are saying and what other interesting information is available. The complication rates of incontinence and ED he quoted may have been correct one week after surgery, but hardly are what most other studies indicate a year later. I was less than convinced that the patient really knew what his Gleason score was. While its 100% reasonable and helpful to advise people going through this to do research, talk to other patients, get second opinions, explore other options; it's quite unhelpful to present that video as a beacon of light.

Posts.Title: Age 26

Posts.Content: You will get plenty of support here. You already realize you have to select a potentially curative course of action, so that narrows things down. There are several stickies above which discuss what you need to know about several treatment options including surgery, brachytherapy, and radiation. There is also a sticky which refers you to the best written books on the subject, which most believe is by Dr. Patrick Walsh. Do a lot of reading to get more in depth information. Your numbers indicate that treatment is necessary, not this month but perhaps within a few months. Having some biopsied samples with Gleason 4, your are between Gleason 3 which is the least aggressive to Gleason 5, the most. So a 4+3 is a combination of two Gleason scores. Your criteria should include the best course of action which aligns to the longest possible cure since you have a lot of years of living to go. Side effects come with the territory which are discussed. Don't be afraid to get at least one opinion from a urologist and radiation oncologist. If you aren't comfortable at any point, get a second opinion. Depending on where you live, one of the opinions could be from a mecca for urology such as Mayo or Cleveland Clinic. When you do some reading and have more specific questions, make sure you post again. Best to you going forward!

Posts.Title: New Member Confused by the numbers

Posts.Content: Going through my checklist to get ready: 1. Recliner ready for sleeping- check 2. Lost 7 lbs, but didn't reach the goal of 15- partial check 3. Working out at the gym at least 4 days a week- check 4. Kegels- doing them every day, sometimes less than the therapist wants but at least what Mayo wants- partial check 5. Incontinence products purchased and ready- check. (Hoping to return some if I get lucky) 6. Post surgery meds purchased including Viagra generic- check 7. Plastic bags and or plastic pail ready for night bag- check 8. Post RALP appointment made with physical therapist- check 9. Mowing and landscaping companies hired to avoid lifting- check What am I missing? I admit the prospect of any surgery is scary, and the idea of a temporary catheter is a hurdle, but trying to keep positive. The extra curve ball for me is the liposarcoma found by the MRI that has to be removed at the same time.

Posts.Content: First, I wish everyone the best in whichever path they take going forward. When I was making my decision I asked several urologists whether G6 can progress to G7/higher (assuming the biopsy or pathology is spot on) and was told there is no definitive answer, but there was a likelihood it would not. The study Dj included above may have some insights, but you need to pay to read it. I did find another study that has some interesting detailed information that some may find helpful. It's small and done in Korea, but not sure how much that matters. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5419108/

Posts.Title: Progression and treatment rates using an AS protocol with mpMRI-guided biopsies

Posts.Content: Some basic questions arise. Of those that started with Gleason 3+3, how many advanced into Gleason 7 or higher? What was the relationship between their PSA and an increase in the Gleason score? For those that started with Gleason 3+4, it can be argued that the "4" became more prevalent which is consistent with Gleason 6 being more benign. When the Gleason 6 advances, that would be concerning to those who are basing their decision on AS that low volume Gleason 6 is very low risk.

Posts.Content: Going through my checklist to get ready: 1. Recliner ready for sleeping- check 2. Lost 7 lbs, but didn't reach the goal of 15- partial check 3. Working out at the gym at least 4 days a week- check 4. Kegels- doing them every day, sometimes less than the therapist wants but at least what Mayo wants- partial check 5. Incontinence products purchased and ready- check. (Hoping to return some if I get lucky) 6. Post surgery meds purchased including Viagra generic- check 7. Plastic bags and or plastic pail ready for night bag- check 8. Post RALP appointment made with physical therapist- check 9. Mowing and landscaping companies hired to avoid lifting- check What am I missing? I admit the prospect of any surgery is scary, and the idea of a temporary catheter is a hurdle, but trying to keep positive. The extra curve ball for me is the liposarcoma found by the MRI that has to be removed at the same time.

Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: Sounds like you are model patient, unlike me. While I'm closing in on continence, I'm not quite there yet. If I had to guess I would say the cough I had which lingered from the cold I had prior to RALP caused me to heal more slowly. At least that's my guess- why wouldn't coughing be deleterious to healing? Your PSA is better than mine also even with your Gleason 7. My last PSA was .06, up from the first one of .03. So I will be getting ready for PSA anxiety for the next blood test hoping that it doesn't go up again. My advice is to go to Black Angus and have a nice meal!

Posts.Title: 6 Month Prostate PSA Results

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to see that you got the result that nobody wants to get, but it sounds like you have a great attitude and will do well based on early detection and early treatment. I'm close to you in our health background- basically very healthy otherwise. Since you have a history with the urologist I'm guessing you have a comfort level with him, although it would be good to find out more about his experience level doing surgeries. The best of luck to you and skill to your surgeon. Let us know if you have any questions.

Posts.Title: first biopsy

Posts.Content: First, I wish everyone the best in whichever path they take going forward. When I was making my decision I asked several urologists whether G6 can progress to G7/higher (assuming the biopsy or pathology is spot on) and was told there is no definitive answer, but there was a likelihood it would not. The study Dj included above may have some insights, but you need to pay to read it. I did find another study that has some interesting detailed information that some may find helpful. It's small and done in Korea, but not sure how much that matters. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5419108/

Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: I might be slightly bending the rules but I'm hoping I will be indulged as I know there are a lot of people here who have been through a lot and I don't know where to turn. About 2.5 weeks ago I started getting headaches and a hard time concentrating along with a diminished appetite and energy. No cold symptoms. Started feeling somewhat better but then worse as I got a post viral cough which I've had many times over the last 30 years- have had complete workups for that and nothing found. Last Friday saw the NP-was negative for flu strains and she didn't offer much except if my fever got over 100 or my coughing lasted more than 18 hours, call the office. My temperature this week has been pretty stable, although now it's 99.7. Am down about 10 lbs which isn't surprising based on my intake. Not feeling normal. Any thoughts would be appreciated.

Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: Some basic questions arise. Of those that started with Gleason 3+3, how many advanced into Gleason 7 or higher? What was the relationship between their PSA and an increase in the Gleason score? For those that started with Gleason 3+4, it can be argued that the "4" became more prevalent which is consistent with Gleason 6 being more benign. When the Gleason 6 advances, that would be concerning to those who are basing their decision on AS that low volume Gleason 6 is very low risk.

Posts.Title: How long is PSA testing needed after RP?

Posts.Content: I was 0.03 after 6 weeks, 0.06 after 4.5 months, and then 0.05 after 7.5 months. My urologist tells me there are traces of PSA in saliva, so it's too early to push any panic buttons. I realize that your situation is somewhat different than mine in terms of pathology. The angst over the periodic PSA test post RALP is definitely unnerving. There's also a small margin of error as there is on most tests, and and if you dropped back 0.01 that would be a significant reduction percentage wise while perhaps not as significant in terms of the absolute number. Did they recommend you have another PSA done in 3 months instead of dropping back to 6? I would suggest that you not worry too much until you have another test to compare with the 0.06. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Post RALP - Incontinence progression?

Posts.Content: I had both tests and the anticipation was the worst part of the process. For the bone scan they inject the tracer and then you wait a few hours before they do the test. Totally painless and nothing to concern yourself about. The 3T CT scan was also easy as all you have to do is lie there without moving much. If you are very claustrophobic you might have a concern, but it was nothing compared to the old tube CT scan a generation or two of technology ago. Waiting for results is yet another story- I am a nervous Nellie but you may have a different personality. Relax!

Posts.Title: BONE and CAT Scan - what to except

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 With a G6 and organ confined disease, looks like congrats are in order! Are u using the uPSA, and if so what is the Uro's logic behind that, given your very low risk status? In your case it may cause more PSA anxiety than is really necessary. You are <.1 on all three tests, and with a G6 that is all u need to know. Good health to u, MM The urologist has requested the "Bayer CIA" PSA test. I don't know if that's uPSA or not. Another reason for my anxiety was my high genetic test score. The first urologist said he never saw a score that high with my biopsy. I've read some anecdotes when this disease doesn't follow the normal pattern expected. I realize that my situation is on the low end of the spectrum, but when it's happening to you it's always a personal thing no matter what the numbers are. Good health to you also!

Posts.Title: 7.5 months post RALP

Posts.Content: Saw the urologist today for my quarterly follow up. Last two PSAs were 0.03 and 0.06, so I was anxious. This time it was 0.05, which seems to stabilize things and reduce worries that a trend was beginning. I had him check a protrusion above his incision, and as I suspected it was a hernia. I had one in the groin area 20 years ago. Has anyone dealt with one in this region? He said it was up to me whether I wanted to have it repaired- no immediacy noted. Incontinence is down to a light shield without getting soaked. It's been a long haul in this regard but there has been consistent progress. ED post RALP is still ongoing, but still too early to give up hope. I wish everyone well!

Posts.Title: 7.5 months post RALP

Posts.Content: Very happy for you! How long was it before you turned the corner with ED? Hard to say how long it will take to tuck this experience away and keep it there. Everyone is different in dealing with health issues, stress, etc. My guess is the longer the time is between PSA checks, the easier it becomes. Every 3 months its still hard not to be guarded, but maybe when you graduate to every year you'll get a small reminder which will pass quickly with a good report.

Posts.Title: Is it time to worry?

Posts.Content: Welcome to the post RALP hernia club. I developed one also. Mine doesn't bother me much as of yet. From what I understand, any underlying scar tissue near the hernia can make any fix more difficult. If mine could be done laparoscopically I might be more motivated to get it over and done with. But there is a good chance that the recuperation could involve 6 weeks of downtime if it can't. Let us know what the surgeon says.

Posts.Title: Approaching 1st Year Post RALP

Posts.Content: Another- did yours bother you? What were your restrictions after the open repair? My primary care doctor and urologist recommend not treating it unless it's bothering me. I wouldn't know if have one if I didn't see a small protrusion. On a scale of 1-10 for ache or pain, mine is a 1.
Posts.Title: Approaching 1st Year Post RALP

Posts.Content: I was close to in the same situation as you. I have 2 Gleason 6 cores. As I went through a battery of tests including biopsy, bone scan, MRI, CT scans, and bone biopsy I found myself stressed out before and especially so waiting for results. What tilted the scale for me was the genetic test- high risk for either having higher grade cancer than what the biopsy found or high risk in it getting more aggressive. I'm having surgery in a few weeks which is only my second surgery ever, and I share your concern about surgeries, especially those that are lengthy. Side effects are troubling for whatever period of time one might experience them, although the statistics suggest that it may be a matter of time before they are overcome. There is no free lunch here, as I'm sure I will be stressed waiting for each subsequent PSA, although less so down the line assuming good initial results. The best to you and your path forward!

Posts.Title: Surveillance to delay treatment, decision time?

Posts.Content: When I had my biopsy the samples were sent to do a genetic test- OncotypeDx GPS. The results included the risk of metastasis to the bone in the next 10 years and also the likelihood of death in the next 10 years. I don't know if that test is done for Gleason 9 as you unfortunately have. Another factor to consider is that prostate cancer that moves to the bone is quite painful. I am dealing with incontinence post surgery, so I understand your concerns. Hopefully it won't be a long term issue, but nobody is given any guarantees even though the odds are good in overcoming it. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Surgery Dec 1st Prostatectomy is it worth it

Posts.Content: I got three urologists opinion- one from the Cleveland Clinic which is about a 5 hour drive for me. The first local urologist's recommendations did not make sense, so I got one more locally and one from one of the top hospitals. I also got a RO opinion. I decided the local surgeon had a lot of positive recommendations and experience, so I didn't see the benefit from having the surgery done in Cleveland where I would have no support system. I would suggest you go to JH for at least one of your opinions unless there is an insurance/financial problem constraint. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Wayne Huizenga

Posts.Content: Sorry that you are here, but you will get a lot of ideas and experience coming to you. I have a lot less G6 than you have, and I had the OncotypeDx GPS test push me to taking care of it sooner rather than later. Did your URO recommend a 3T MRI? If not, I would strongly recommend that you do that prior to coming up with a game plan. It will help determine if there is anything else involved beyond the capsule, which (with G6) is unlikely. The other consideration is whether you are the type of person who will be at peace waiting for each PSA with the potential for upward trends along with more biopsies even if AS was offered. As MM has stated, it would be out of the mainstream to consider active surveillance.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results back - Feel like squirrel crossing busy street

Posts.Content: From the ASCO Post: "Dr. Epstein: Because a pure Gleason 6 score determined at radical prostatectomy—where you can examine the entire tumor—has no risk of metastasizing and no risk of leading to the patient’s death, some people question whether we should call Gleason 6 an indolent lesion of epithelial origin (or IDLE) rather than cancer. But morphologically, Gleason 6 is cancer. It looks like a higher-grade cancer under the microscope. It can invade nerves and extend outside of the prostate and has all the features of local aggressiveness that you don’t see with benign tumors."

Posts.Title: Surgery Dec 1st Prostatectomy is it worth it

Posts.Content: This article provides several reasons including what was discussed above as to elevated PSA readings: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/sc...rostate-cancer I took the OncotypeDx GPS and I was high risk with a mortality rate of 1% over the next 10 years. Your Prolaris score seems to indicate that you are high risk also, although I admit not knowing much about Prolaris. Were you given any counseling in that regard by your urologist? Have you had a recent 3T MRI? If not, maybe it's time to discuss it. Good luck!

Posts.Title: PSA continues to rise

Posts.Content: From the ASCO Post: "Dr. Epstein: Because a pure Gleason 6 score determined at radical prostatectomy—where you can examine the entire tumor—has no risk of metastasizing and no risk of leading to the patient’s death, some people question whether we should call Gleason 6 an indolent lesion of epithelial origin (or IDLE) rather than cancer. But morphologically, Gleason 6 is cancer. It looks like a higher-grade cancer under the microscope. It can invade nerves and extend outside of the prostate and has all the features of local aggressiveness that you don’t see with benign tumors."

Posts.Title: Recent articles on Gleason Grading

Posts.Content: When I had my biopsy the samples were sent to do a genetic test- OncotypeDx GPS. The results included the risk of metastasis to the bone in the next 10 years and also the likelihood of death in the next 10 years. I don't know if that test is done for Gleason 9 as you unfortunately have. Another factor to consider is that prostate cancer that moves to the bone is quite painful. I am dealing with incontinence post surgery, so I understand your concerns. Hopefully it won't be a long term issue, but nobody is given any guarantees even though the odds are good in overcoming it. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Surgery Dec 1st Prostatectomy is it worth it

Posts.Content: Sorry that you're joining us here. With the stage you're in, surgery is probably not the optimal treatment, but at least get an opinion from a Radiation Oncologist and Medical Oncologist besides your Urologist. With surgery, the younger you are and the better your erections are prior to surgery give you a higher chance to regain potency as long as at least one nerve is spared (preferably both depending on what they see during surgery). You should expect at least some time period where erections would be difficult, but with optimal conditions I've seen odds being as high as 85% after a recovery period. Odds improve with the skill and experience of the surgeon. There are aids which can help things along during the recovery. Radiation can effect potency, but usually takes a longer time before that happens. Hormone therapy reduces your testosterone which has side effects, but doesn't last forever. The doctors can give you a better idea about that along with men here who have gone through these treatments. I'm sure this is a big shock, especially since you probably feel fine and this came out of nowhere. Look for the best treatment overall for you based on whatever criteria is most important to both of you. Doctors will prioritize keeping you alive as first and foremost. Good luck, don't get ahead of yourself, be hopeful and do your homework. You might want to get the latest prostate cancer book by Doctor Patrick Walsh which is listed in one of the sticky's above which addresses most everything.

Posts.Title: Dribbling has increased

Posts.Content: Sorry that you are here, but you will get a lot of ideas and experience coming to you. I have a lot less G6 than you have, and I had the OncotypeDx GPS test push me to taking care of it sooner rather than later. Did your URO recommend a 3T MRI? If not, I would strongly recommend that you do that prior to coming up with a game plan. It will help determine if there is anything else involved beyond the capsule, which (with G6) is unlikely. The other consideration is whether you are the type of person who will be at peace waiting for each PSA with the potential for upward trends along with more biopsies even if AS was offered. As MM has stated, it would be out of the mainstream to consider active surveillance.

Posts.Title: Sildenafil

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic See [#59] Does penile rehabilitation have a role in the treatment of erectile dysfunction following radical prostatectomy? [2017] just added in the Special Studies & Report Subforum. When I told my doc at my first post-op visit 3 months after my RP that I had started 20 mg sildenafil every night after catheter the was out to help with blood flow and the return of (nocturnal) erections, he said there was no proof it helped with recovery, but that there was certainly no harm in trying, especially since it is relative cheap (his group practice sells it at $1/20 mg and it can be found even cheaper). See the above review paper, especially regarding the results of trials comparing low daily doses to on-demand doses. It seems reasonable to think daily doses to improve the blood supply could help with recovery even though there dosn't appear to be proof. I saw your study, but I added a different study in the ED section awhile ago. Had you seen this, or do you think the newer study is flawed? https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29307683

Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: In hospital 2 nights- I did not want to be discharged after one night due to the high pain level. They gave me a hug buddy to clutch to my stomach every time I had to cough, and during the coughing the pain was as high as I ever have experienced. Pain started to improve 4 days after the surgery when I was passing gas and having bowel movements. Perhaps this was in part due to the extra surgery removing a tumor behind my bladder. Maybe I should have taken the more powerful pain meds but I was reluctant to do so.

Pain started to improve 4 days after the surgery when I was passing gas and having bowel movements. Perhaps this was in part due to the extra surgery removing a tumor behind my bladder. Maybe I should have taken the more powerful pain meds but I was reluctant to do so.

Posts.Content: It's very difficult to give you a specific surgeon. I have had a few people I know go to either UCLA or Cedars-Sinai, both located in LA and both high volume and highly regarded facilities. You might want to make appointments with more than one surgeon and see how comfortable you are with them and make sure they have sufficient experience, the more robotic surgeries the better..

Posts.Title: Dad has aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I'm sure you will get others with similar numbers to share their advice/experience. The one part I may be able to provide some advice on is the Cleveland Clinic. I made an appointment with them to get a second opinion with a Urologist, and I though it was well worth the trip. However, it's unlikely that Urology will be providing much information about radiation options. If you haven't already done so, contact the Clinic and try to get a second appointment the same day with a radiation oncologist. I wish you the best going forward for all involved.

Posts.Content: I'm sure you will get others with similar numbers to share their advice/experience. The one part I may be able to provide some advice on is the Cleveland Clinic. I made an appointment with them to get a second opinion with a Urologist, and I though it was well worth the trip. However, it's unlikely that Urology will be providing much information about radiation options. If you haven't already done so, contact the Clinic and try to get a second appointment the same day with a radiation oncologist. I wish you the best going forward for all involved.

Posts.Title: Dad has aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Within 24 hours of surgery I was limited to liquids, clear broths, and plain jello. I probably tapered down a little bit before that, but nothing specific. Assuming you are going to have general anesthesia, I don't think any solid food is appropriate the day before surgery. After surgery I just listened to my body- didn't feel like anything heavy for a few days so I ate tuna, eggs, soups, etc. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer I was told by my urologist that there can be small amounts of detectable PSA from saliva. Here is one study about it. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11096235

Posts.Title: BPH symptoms?

Posts.Content: First, you can't judge progress day to day. I assessed my progress month to month and found that to be a better yardstick. I went from full underwear (Depends) to pads and then to shields. At 15 months I am not declaring 100% continence as I do have minor leaks occasionally. However, I am still seeing progress in less leaking even at this stage. I did formal physical therapy incorporating kegels into my routine and while I think it's helpful, there is a certain amount of healing that needs to take place depending on the surgeon and your specific situation. My advice is not to get overly stressed about it, especially considering that you are just beginning the healing process.

Posts.Content: If you are getting lost in the bureaucracy I wouldn't hesitate (after a reasonable amount of time) to contact one of your Congressional representatives to assist. When my mother passed away I thought I was in a game of 3 card Monty with SSA. After waiting 3 months one inquiry from my representative and it was resolved in 3 business days.

Posts.Title: Husband died from cancer, Widow of Veteran in Need

Posts.Content: Sorry that you had a need to find us here. First, don't get ahead of yourself. A CT scan is painless and easy unless you can't lay fairly still for 20 minutes or so. If your urologist doesn't schedule you for a 3T MRI, ask about it and get one scheduled. Was this your first PSA? Any family history? A "slightly" enlarged prostate is not unusual at your age, but the feel test isn't definitive as to how enlarged it is. DREs tend to increase the PSA temporarily, but your PSA is high so you need additional testing. Depending on the CT and MRI, a bone scan may be recommended. A biopsy of your prostate is also likely. Yes, this is all disquieting but don't assume the worst but do follow up with requisite testing in order to find out what is going on and then depending, what are the options. Others will chime in also. Keep your head up!

Posts.Title: Atlanta/metro Atlanta urologist referral?

Posts.Content: I had a somewhat different DRE experience. One urologist thought he felt something, and the biopsy was positive for some low volume Gleason 6 which was at the point where the PSA jumped. He was not going to offer nerve sparing during surgery, so I got a few other opinions. Three other urologists, including one from the Cleveland Clinic and one PA felt nothing suspicious. MRI was negative for any extension. My take is that there are some things clearly concerning, while some are a very subjective call.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA = 0.00 !

Posts.Content: I asked the urologist if I could time my latest PSA to coincide with my yearly physical blood work. I like to time my stress to get all the news in one bundle. 9/25 RALP 11/8 0.03 2/8 0.06 (hmm) 5/3 0.05 9/6 0.03 Yes, every 6 months at least for the upcoming year. I guess that's subject to change if there is reason to do so. My blood pressure is back to a good normal (124/84) after it peaked during the process of getting several opinions to include the Cleveland Clinic- they were quite concerned of my 195/95. I have white coat syndrome and after having two unsatisfactory urology consultations and an unnecessary bone biopsy I felt like I was getting nowhere fast.

Posts.Title: The one year mark

Posts.Content: Got my latest PSA test back and it's 0.03. That follows the first 3 checks of 0.03 (6 weeks), 0.06, and 0.05. With all the discussion about how 0.03 is suggested as a line of demarcation of possible further treatment, I'm satisfied that there is no upward trend as of yet. I visit the urologist Friday and see what he says. My continence is not 100% yet, but I don't think it's plateaued. My estimate is that I'm 95-98%. For those that state that continence should be reached by 6 months, I suggest you not make that so definitive so those who are still on the path don't get discouraged. Never had ED until the surgery but no improvement since then. Took Sildenafil until last month and then I switched over to Tadalafil once I found a pharmacy that compounds it locally and the cost is much better than I have seen elsewhere. Figure I will give it a few months more of a test before maybe switching back to Sildenafil. Thanks to those providing insights and support. I dislike it when things get chippy here in questioning peoples motives and am glad it doesn't happen a lot. Finally, my best to those in every stage of treatment. When I read some of the difficult posts my heart sinks but when others chime in with positive responses it makes me feel as this board is doing wonderful work!

Posts.Title: The one year mark

Posts.Content: My 3 month PSA stress checks have been modified to every 6 months. Was told to try 20 mg of tadalafil once a month to see if I could prime the pump with the expectation there will be more nerve healing during year 2. Years ago my ulnar nerve got aggravated, and it took many months for it to improve. Then during kegel physical therapy I was given side planks to do while kegeling which aggravated it again. It's taken months for it to resolve, so hopefully the same healing will happen internally with more time.

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed and overwhelmed

Posts.Content: First, you can't judge progress day to day. I assessed my progress month to month and found that to be a better yardstick. I went from full underwear (Depends) to pads and then to shields. At 15 months I am not declaring 100% continence as I do have minor leaks occasionally. However, I am still seeing progress in less leaking even at this stage. I did formal physical therapy incorporating kegels into my routine and while I think it's helpful, there is a certain amount of healing that needs to take place depending on the surgeon and your specific situation. My advice is not to get overly stressed about it, especially considering that you are just beginning the healing process.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed with Ductal Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer I was told by my urologist that there can be small amounts of detectable PSA from saliva. Here is one study about it. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11096235

Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: I looked at a study about outcomes following prostatectomy and SRT. In the detail of the study it states that of the men studied, 599 (24%) had Gleason less than or equal to 6. What would cause so many men with pathology of a 6 to undergo SRT? http://ascopubs.org/doi/figure/10.1200/JCO.2016.67.9647 I then tried a predictive calculator, which if you only have Gleason 6 with no sign of leaving the capsule and a PSA of 0.01, there's still a 24% chance of 10 year biochemical failure. Why would it be that high? Why is metastasis 4% instead of 0? http://riskcalc.org/ProstateCancerAf...statectomyNew/

Posts.Title: Other PSA testing options - list needed

Posts.Content: Sorry that you had a need to find us here. First, don't get ahead of yourself. A CT scan is painless and easy unless you can't lay fairly still for 20 minutes or so. If your urologist doesn't schedule you for a 3T MRI, ask about it and get one scheduled. Was this your first PSA? Any family history? A "slightly" enlarged prostate is not unusual at your age, but the feel test isn't definitive as to how enlarged it is. DREs tend to increase the PSA temporarily, but your PSA is high so you need additional testing. Depending on the CT and MRI, a bone scan may be recommended. A biopsy of your prostate is also likely. Yes, this is all disquieting but don't assume the worst but do follow up with requisite testing in order to find out what is going on and then depending, what are the options. Others will chime in also. Keep your head up!

Posts.Title: Newbie with alot of questions and concerns

Posts.Content: Doesnt statistically say at this high number generally points towards a higher cancer risk?[/QUOTE] Generally yes, but your concern and plan of action is about your specific situation which you won't know until after testing and the biopsy. In the meanwhile, you might want to do some reading, especially Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It might even be available at a local library.

Hope it helps and if it does, would like to hear what made things easier for you. https://www.nationalincontinence.com...Guards_for_Men
Posts.Title: Severe Incontinence following surgery - Some questions ?

Posts.Content: Today is my pre-surgical exam combined with my yearly physical. I asked my primary care doctor to request a PSA even though it wasn't in his original order, and in 4 months my PSA rose once again, this time to 9.77. Even though I'm not happy about having surgery in a few weeks, if I was on AS this would stress me out to no end. I'm sufficiently stressed with the upcoming surgery! Is there any information that correlates PSA with the Gleason grade found?

Posts.Title: Pre-surgical exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Stress is difficult. I wish you some peace these next days. I am hearing a lot of guys saying their PSA is not necessarily a linear change, more a bouncing number. This weekend I have met many guys on AS for many years and I am choosing to look at it as delayed treatment. Maybe they will perfect things like laser ablation or invent something new. Again I wish you well. Denis Thanks for the support. I think my first URO did me no favors when he wanted me to do surgery quickly without any hope for nerve sparing based on my genetic test score. That sent me into a deep hole which took me several consultations to get my head back above water. Then when one of the consultations found an additional tumor, back down I went. I wish you the best also in making the best choice going forward!

Posts.Title: Pre-surgical exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F C1: Understandable that there is stress. Try to view this from a different perspective: I am having surgery to permanently cure me of Prostate Cancer. Re "Is there any information that correlates PSA with the Gleason grade found?:" Here is a paper that addresses that question: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4186957/ Stay focussed on arriving on the other side of surgery. For most, the surgery was no more than a major inconvenience. Good luck & best wishes for a soft landing and clean Path Report! MF Thanks for the link- I had not seen that before. There is such a divergence of outcomes and there doesn't appear to be any specific factors which predict where a person will fall within that spectrum. I would think being healthy and active would help considerably, but that didn't make a difference in getting where I am today. I'm doing kegels, getting all of my meds and continence products in advance, and trying to get as much else done beforehand so I can focus on recuperation and walking. Appreciate your good wishes!

Posts.Title: Pre-surgical exam

Posts.Content: I was mostly caffeine free prior to the surgery, and have been even more diligent in also not consuming carbonated or alcoholic beverages post surgery. I had no bladder spasms, but continence is an issue (mostly dribbles but fairly frequent). All you can do is the best you can to optimize success, but after eliminating potential irritants you can always add them back one at a time later to see if it makes a difference. My surgeon was trained in RALPs in 2003 and has been doing them regularly since then, so he was no novice.

Posts.Title: AS, a presentation by my doc

Posts.Content: I asked the urologist if I could time my latest PSA to coincide with my yearly physical blood work. I like to time my stress to get all the news in one bundle. 9/25 RALP 11/8 0.03 2/8 0.06 (hmm) 5/3 0.05 9/6 0.03 Yes, every 6 months at least for the upcoming year. I guess that's subject to change if there is reason to do so. My blood pressure is back to a good normal (124/84) after it peaked during the process of getting several opinions to include the Cleveland Clinic- they were quite concerned of my 195/95. I have white coat syndrome and after having two unsatisfactory urology consultations and an unnecessary bone biopsy I felt like I was getting nowhere fast.

Posts.Title: The one year mark

Posts.Content: My 3 month PSA stress checks have been modified to every 6 months. Was told to try 20 mg of tadalafil once a month to see if I could prime the pump with the expectation there will be more nerve healing during year 2. Years ago my ulnar nerve got aggravated, and it took many months for it to improve. Then during kegel physical therapy I was given side planks to do while kegeling which aggravated it again. It's taken months for it to resolve, so hopefully the same healing will happen internally with more time.

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: You ask a very legitimate question. I started a thread which questions the same thing in a different manner. https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-am-I-missing Based on the science, the only hypothesis is leftover cells. But is that the cause of every case? Is some Gleason 6 acting differently? We rely on the science to make decisions, and if there are exceptions to the rule nobody seems to know much about it. Posts.Content: You ask a very legitimate question. I started a thread which questions the same thing in a different manner. https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-am-I-missing Based on the science, the only hypothesis is leftover cells. But is that the cause of every case? Is some Gleason 6 acting differently? We rely on the science to make decisions, and if there are exceptions to the rule nobody seems to know much about it. Let us know what your RO says about this.

Posts.Content: From what I have researched, the surgeon will see how easily the tissue peels off at the edges. If it peels off easily, that typically indicates no cancer. If it's sticky, then they either have take out more or do pathology during the surgery to decide (if they have the capability to do that). I rejected my first urologist based on him saying he would automatically take out the nerve bundles based almost solely on my genetic test results. I want someone who will make decisions based on the circumstances they find during the surgery- I wouldn't expect a guarantee of nerve sparing or nerve ending in advance unless there was conclusive evidence from an MRI or some other test.

Posts.Title: William Shatner & PSA

Posts.Content: The first test my urologist ordered after the prostate biopsy was a bone scan. I had two cores with Gleason 6 and my PSA was 7.49. Because there was a questionable rib from the scan, I had to endure a stressful bone biopsy which was not a fun way to spend a Friday. Then more stress until the result finally was released a week later, and fortunately it was negative. Since then I have tried to determine if that course of action was appropriate or not. According to Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer, he doesn't recommend a scan unless the PSA is higher than 20, or Gleason greater than 7, or Stage T3 or greater. This criteria is similar to what Dr. Chodak recommends as he states that 13% of the scans have a questionable result which leads to a biopsy. His statistics are that only 3 of 1000 biopsy's lead to a positive finding for cancer in the bone when that criteria isn't used. Maybe this will help someone in a similar situation. From what I have read a 3T MRI should have been the first test ordered. Are there others with a different take on this? By the way, my first urologist is no longer my urologist.

AgeInfo.Phrase: His statistics are that only 3 of 1000 biopsy's lead to

Posts.Title: Bone scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Consult1! Sorry that you underwent a bone (rib) biopsy but very glad that it proved to be (-)! Did any of these MDs ever ask you: "Did you have a previous rib injury or fracture?" IMO, bone scans following diagnosis of PC with a PSA < 10 are of little clinical value. Bone scans certainly make lots of $ for the local hospital and helps that URO's hospital profile. As you found out, bones scans are not specific for CA. A (+) finding only leads to further investigation = Biopsy. Suggestion: Keep a record of the total billed costs encountered for: - Bone Scan Bill - Radiologist's Bill to read the scan - Rib Biopsy - Path Lab Bill and Pathologist's Bill I will "guess" that the total $ is substantial. And a 100% waste of time and money. Keep us updated with your new URO MDs recommendations. MF Thanks for your comments. Before I had the bone biopsy I had x-rays, which seemed to indicate that the rib "lesion" wasn't cancer, but they leave enough wiggle (or weasel) room such that they aren't definitive. If I had an injury I remembered I would have told them, but after 67 years of living outside of bubble wrap it's not possible to isolate any possible injury. Yes, its been a nice money maker for the health care providers, and a great way to raise my blood pressure from all the unnecessary stress. My current local urologist is in sync with the opinion I got from the Cleveland Clinic. I have a tumor (liposarcoma) behind the bladder found by the 3T MRI which needs to be removed so I will have one surgery to do both that and the prostate. If not for the OncotypeDx GPS high risk rating of my low volume Gleason 6 in two cores I would have only had the tumor taken out and done AS for the prostate with Cyberknife as my second choice. Like most I'm concerned about the side effects of prostate surgery, especially continence since I'm 100% continent now. I could stand to lose 10 lbs but I'm in the gym 6 times a week working out so hopefully that will help along with kegels I have stared. I know a lot of guys here would gladly trade their higher Gleason scores for mine, but I have always been health conscious to try and avoid any such interventions. Surgery is set for Sept 25...

Posts.Content: The mean streets of Orange County may do it a bit differently, but my doc is ordering a Cystogram to evaluate whether the catheter can be safely removed. I had a minuscule BM at the hospital after some prescription meds, but my first real BM was this morning 4 days post surgery, followed by one in the afternoon and one in the evening. I would imagine that isn't too unusual. Are you taking the colace or something similar? Yes, the pain increases somewhat as you sit up straight or move around, but my pain reaches a pinnacle when I cough. Yes, my catheter drips also, but it seems like its significantly more likely to do so when I am on the porcelain throne. Maybe it's pressure related, although I definitely have been avoiding straining when on my perch. The best to you!

Posts.Title: 2 Days After Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque Doctor, decided to reschedule me to this Thursday at 12 noon, looks like I have 2 more days with Cathy & company. (UGGHH!) Just started noticing that even though Cathy is still in, I always have a slight urge to pee sensation, is that common? Everything seems to be healing nicely, just have one incision on my right side with staples that is moderately swollen, other than that I feel pretty good! Anyway, I will post my post-op stuff and comments later this week for those who would like to see my follow-up. Al I never felt a full urge to urinate, but there might have been some minor urges from time to time. Maybe you are just a little more sensitive to Cathy. As long as you don't have much pain and no bladder spasms, you are doing well. All my incisions are healing well according to 3 different nurses although I did have a lot of bruising. Staples come out with a pinching feeling, and catheter removal was the easiest part of the process so far. Keep up the good work.

Posts.Title: 2 Days After Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Consult1; So sorry to hear you had to go through a bone biopsy. My urologist had me go through a bone scan only because my biopsy was 3+4. He specifically remarked that if I were a 3+3, it would be a waste of money. And even with a 3+4, he also specifically remarked that with such a low psa as I (5.9), he said he highly doubted that the bone scan would be positive. In addition, when I went through the bone scan, I was a little concerned because the technician said she wanted to take a few extra pictures in case the physician ordered them - so for 2 weeks while waiting for the results, I was worried sick but only found out when I asked the doctor that there was a previous injury to my shoulder (which I didn't even know about). So even though they saw something unusual in the bone scan, the doctor apparently knew that this finding was due to an injury and not cancer. I am not sure why your urologist had you submit to a bone biopsy with only a 3+3 and such low psa (under 10) but I think I would be hesitant to keep that doctor. In my opinion, I would look for a different urologist. Tim Yes, my first urologist is my former urologist. I went to the top robotic surgeon in this area as a second opinion (over 4000 Davinci's) and wasn't impressed with his lack of knowing the basics of my case nor him not being concerned not having MRI results at that point. So I went to a 3rd urologist who probably has done around 1000, and I was impressed with his understanding of my case and a path forward. He ordered the MRI and found a liposarcoma behind my bladder. It sounded like my first urologist may have been reluctant to order an MRI because it would be more work for him to get it approved. He has impeccable credentials on paper (residence at top hospital system), but that doesn't tell the full story. Other than giving feedback to my primary care doctor who referred me, I guess the only other way I have of warning others is to post a review on Healthgrades or Vitals.
