Posts.Title: William Shatner & PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque Doctor, decided to reschedule me to this Thursday at 12 noon, looks like I have 2 more days with Cathy & company. (UGGHH!) Just started noticing that even though Cathy is still in, I always have a slight urge to pee sensation, is that common? Everything seems to be healing nicely, just have one incision on my right side with staples that is moderately swollen, other than that I feel pretty good! Anyway, I will post my post-op stuff and comments later this week for those who would like to see my follow-up. Al I never felt a full urge to urinate, but there might have been some minor urges from time to time. Maybe you are just a little more sensitive to Cathy. As long as you don't have much pain and no bladder spasms, you are doing well. All my incisions are healing well according to 3 different nurses although I did have a lot of bruising. Staples come out with a pinching feeling, and catheter removal was the easiest part of the process so far. Keep up the good work.

Posts.Title: 2 Days After Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: From what I have researched, the surgeon will see how easily the tissue peels off at the edges. If it peels off easily, that typically indicates no cancer. If it's sticky, then they either have take out more or do pathology during the surgery to decide (if they have the capability to do that). I rejected my first urologist based on him saying he would automatically take out the nerve bundles based almost solely on my genetic test results. I want someone who will make decisions based on the circumstances they find during the surgery- I wouldn't expect a guarantee of nerve sparing or nerve ending in advance unless there was conclusive evidence from an MRI or some other test.

Posts.Content: My surgery is in about a month. I had a meeting with the physical therapist already and she wanted to see me a month after the surgery for a second meeting. One thing I want to get out of it is to find out how I can safely ease back into an exercise routine after not being able to lift anything more than 10 lbs or so and not doing any vigorous cardio. I assume she will also do some kegel follow up.

Posts.Content: I don't have a specific therapist to recommend, but when you're doing your search you might check to see if any potential therapist has completed the specialty pelvic floor certification course by APTA (American Physical Therapy Association).

Posts.Title: Need Physical Therapist Recommendation Daytona Beach area

Posts.Content: After a fairly stable PSA of 4.0 (plus/minus 0.15) for 3 straight 6 month readings, it jumped up to 7.49 in May 2017. Biopsy in June revealed left and right apex Gleason 6, one less than 5% and the other core 35%. Dr. ordered an OncotypeDx GPS genetic test on the Gleason 6 cores and it came back high risk- a 43 score. Volume of prostate 50-60 cc. He wanted to schedule surgery with no nerve sparing possibility which sent me into a daze. Got a few other opinions after that, and the Dr. I felt most comfortable with (he started doing DaVinci's in 2003) ordered a 3T MRI which didn't show anything new regarding the prostate but did show a small growth behind the bladder which is probably a liposarcoma. Of the opinions I have sought, only the original Dr. seemed to feel anything unusual on the prostate. At the Cleveland Clinic the urologist said if it wasn't for the genetic test showing high risk, I would have been a perfect candidate for Active Surveillance- his opinion was that I'm a T1c. All urologists with the exception of the first think that nerve sparing is very likely. The original Dr. ordered a bone scan, which revealed one rib with a "lesion", which from what I can tell can mean nothing or something. I've read Gleason 6 almost never spreads beyond the prostate unless the biopsy didn't find the most aggressive portion. But my MRI didn't indicate there was more involved. So I was referred to a Ortho Oncologist and she ordered a bone biopsy (not a lot of fun) and am now waiting for the results with even more stress on top of everything. I will need at least an operation to remove the small tumor, but talked to Radiation Oncologists about Cyberknife and HDR Bracytherapy. While I'm a devout coward when it comes to surgery and at least temporary side effects, it seems to make the most sense to have one operation for both and not go through two different treatments. I'm healthy (other than my stress levels getting my blood pressure up higher than normal) and take no meds. A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details.
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Thanks. I was considering doing it at the Cleveland Clinic with the urologist that saw me, but he didn't have any more robotic surgery experience than the local urologist. Then there are logistics to consider as far as staying in the Cleveland area for at least a week or so. I'm agnostic about whether to pursue radiation or surgery- from the studies I have seen the percentages for 10 year side effects are slightly better for radiation. However, since I have to have surgery for the tumor with general anesthesia, I thought it would just be better to do them both together. I will be on edge until I get the bone scan results to finalize things. I hope you continue to progress from your surgery for a complete recovery.
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Thanks for weighing in. I strongly considered radiation, and actually might have picked it if it wasn't for the tumor behind my bladder that has to be surgically removed with general anesthesia. There are risks of side effects possible no matter which course of treatment is selected, but from my review of data the likelihood is somewhat less for radiation (at least for 10 year data). My only concern with SBRT (which was my initial preference) is that not only do they give high doses of radiation to kill off the cancer in the prostate with more precise margins, but they also expose the urethra to the same high doses. Maybe that wont be an issue in the long run, but its not settled yet. Yes, I am concerned about the side effects of surgery, but it seems you pay the price up front and usually things improve (fingers crossed).

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: My belief is that until you are healed sufficiently from the surgery, the low or high number of kegels you do is not going to get you continent. You do kegels to put you in the best position to avoid stress incontinence, but if you don't have control over small leaks and squirts while you are just standing, I don't think you are fully healed (assuming it's not been more than a year since surgery).

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: It seems like we share a fairly similar going in situation regarding Gleason 6, small tumor volume (3-4% of what was sampled from the blind biopsy), and DRE results. The GPS genetic test just started getting used a few years ago, and from reading the report I have a 40% chance of Gleason greater or equal to 4 plus 3 and a 45% chance of non-organ confined disease. None of the urologists seem to think I currently have this situation from the MRI and DRE, but the bone biopsy was done to be extra sure. It's nerve wracking dealing with probabilities and statistics when it comes to health concerns. It's great that you have kept your PSA down to near zero- I can see myself anxious waiting for the regular intervals of PSAs that follow. One question- after your catheter was removed, does the feeling when you need to urinate change? Is there less of a warning-is that something that needs to be relearned? Any other advise you have would be welcomed!

A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details.
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Thanks for weighing in. I strongly considered radiation, and actually might have picked it if it wasn't for the tumor behind my bladder that has to be surgically removed with general anesthesia. There are risks of side effects possible no matter which course of treatment is selected, but from my review of data the likelihood is somewhat less for radiation (at least for 10 year data). My only concern with SBRT (which was my initial preference) is that not only do they give high doses of radiation to kill off the cancer in the prostate with more precise margins, but they also expose the urethra to the same high doses. Maybe that wont be an issue in the long run, but its not settled yet. Yes, I am concerned about the side effects of surgery, but it seems you pay the price up front and usually things improve (fingers crossed).
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: After a fairly stable PSA of 4.0 (plus/minus 0.15) for 3 straight 6 month readings, it jumped up to 7.49 in May 2017. Biopsy in June revealed left and right apex Gleason 6, one less than 5% and the other core 35%. Dr. ordered an OncotypeDx GPS genetic test on the Gleason 6 cores and it came back high risk- a 43 score. Volume of prostate 50-60 cc. He wanted to schedule surgery with no nerve sparing possibility which sent me into a daze. Got a few other opinions after that, and the Dr. I felt most comfortable with (he started doing DaVinci's in 2003) ordered a 3T MRI which didn't show anything new regarding the prostate but did show a small growth behind the bladder which is probably a liposarcoma. Of the opinions I have sought, only the original Dr. seemed to feel anything unusual on the prostate. At the Cleveland Clinic the urologist said if it wasn't for the genetic test showing high risk, I would have been a perfect candidate for Active Surveillance- his opinion was that I'm a T1c. All urologists with the exception of the first think that nerve sparing is very likely. The original Dr. ordered a bone scan, which revealed one rib with a "lesion", which from what I can tell can mean nothing or something. I've read Gleason 6 almost never spreads beyond the prostate unless the biopsy didn't find the most aggressive portion. But my MRI didn't indicate there was more involved. So I was referred to a Ortho Oncologist and she ordered a bone biopsy (not a lot of fun) and am now waiting for the results with even more stress on top of everything. I will need at least an operation to remove the small tumor, but talked to Radiation Oncologists about Cyberknife and HDR Bracytherapy. While I'm a devout coward when it comes to surgery and at least temporary side effects, it seems to make the most sense to have one operation for both and not go through two different treatments. I'm healthy (other than my stress levels getting my blood pressure up higher than normal) and take no meds. A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details.
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: It seems like we share a fairly similar going in situation regarding Gleason 6, small tumor volume (3-4% of what was sampled from the blind biopsy), and DRE results. The GPS genetic test just started getting used a few years ago, and from reading the report I have a 40% chance of Gleason greater or equal to 4 plus 3 and a 45% chance of non-organ confined disease. None of the urologists seem to think I currently have this situation from the MRI and DRE, but the bone biopsy was done to be extra sure. It's nerve wracking dealing with probabilities and statistics when it comes to health concerns. It's great that you have kept your PSA down to near zero- I can see myself anxious waiting for the regular intervals of PSAs that follow. One question- after your catheter was removed, does the feeling when you need to urinate change? Is there less of a warning-is that something that needs to be relearned? Any other advise you have would be welcomed!
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Thanks. I was considering doing it at the Cleveland Clinic with the urologist that saw me, but he didn't have any more robotic surgery experience than the local urologist. Then there are logistics to consider as far as staying in the Cleveland area for at least a week or so. I'm agnostic about whether to pursue radiation or surgery- from the studies I have seen the percentages for 10 year side effects are slightly better for radiation. However, since I have to have surgery for the tumor with general anesthesia, I thought it would just be better to do them both together. I will be on edge until I get the bone scan results to finalize things. I hope you continue to progress from your surgery for a complete recovery.
Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Good job! I know that it would be great to have triple zeros, but it's less than 0.1 which used to be the yardstick until the test became more precise. My two PSAs post RALP were 0.03 and 0.06- I got a little worked up over it doubling. My doctor says that some saliva produces a PSA like substance which can be in play. It's natural for me to get nervous before the blood test, and then waiting for the results also so I understand your mindset. Let's hope that the numbers stay in the hundredths!

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Been dealing with the usual incontinence for a little over 2 weeks and not near the panic button. However, between wearing the full padded underwear and the moisture that is retained both from leaks and the lack of breathing that is the nature of that type of underwear, the amount of irritation has gotten worse. Decided to switch to guards inside regular underwear today to see if that might help. It's gotten so bad that the irritation has created some small cracks where blood has been seen. Red and raw is the best description. When I walk I tend to walk like a cowboy who has been on a horse too long in order to reduce the friction. Not only has this made life miserable, but it also reduces the amount of walking I can tolerate. Plus, my ankles which had never been swollen pre-surgery are swollen a few hours after waking up- they are ok first thing in the morning. I put my feet up when relaxing. Any ideas, tricks, experiences, etc. to share would be appreciated!

Posts.Content: I don't have a lot of answers for you, but I will share some things I learned from my caregiver experience. There is such a thing as hospital delirium, during which the person is not behaving at all like themselves. It's different than any form of dementia and is temporary in nature. Being in unfamiliar and medical surroundings seems to trigger it. It's important to encourage the person to fully participate in rehab. There are a lot of complications with your father's situation and I don't know what his baseline physical condition was, but as we age it takes longer to recover and the key to reaching your best is to trust in physical/occupational therapists. I motivated my mom to do the therapy as her goal was to try to get back to her house and said that doing the therapy was her best opportunity to do that. Falls can be either a major hit or a minor setback. Therapy should help that. If your father is a veteran there is Aid and Attendance support if he qualifies financially. Hope the best for you and your dad!

Posts.Title: Dad is now in assisted living.

Posts.Content: My emotional side is relieved (unless I'm missing something) from the results. My logical side is wondering if I really needed the surgery. Yes, I know you have to make a decision based on what information the medical people can provide. The liposarcoma turned out to be misdiagnosed (again, I was relieved that it wasn't cancer as expected) which was the motivation to have the surgery (two removals in one surgery) as opposed to other treatments. On the plus side, I don't have to worry about the possibility that the genetic test score was predictive for my Gleason 6 morphing into something worse. For me, the surgery was very painful for the first 6 days which seems to be worse than others who have shared. The other surprise was that the size of my prostate was double what the other tests indicated. Posts.Title: Pathology report is in

Posts.Content: My 3 follow up PSAs to the RALP were 0.03, 0.06, and 0.05. My urologist who has been doing RALPs since 2003 and is the head of urology at my hospital said there is nothing to be concerned about. My pathology is only slightly better than yours. For now I'm buying in to his assessment, but I will continue to remain vigilant and get my PSA taken at whatever intervals are asked of me.

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I decided the local surgeon had a lot of positive recommendations and experience, so I didn't see the benefit from having the surgery done in Cleveland where I would have no support system. I would suggest you go to JH for at least one of your opinions unless there is an insurance/financial problem constraint....
